title: Government of China provides medical supplies to Myanmar in July 2021
description: According to a statement released by the Chinese Embassy in Myanmar on July 2, 2021, the Government of China provided Myanmar with 100,000 surgical masks, 29,760 N95 masks, 12,975 pieces of personal protective equipment (PPE) and 10,000 medical gloves. The purpose of this donation is to aid Myanmar in its fight against COVID-19.
staff_comments: 1. There is a discrepancy with the date that the source claims the donation was made and the date that the article was published.AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Government of China provides medical supplies to Myanmar in July 2021

# Description
According to a statement released by the Chinese Embassy in Myanmar on July 2, 2021, the Government of China provided Myanmar with 100,000 surgical masks, 29,760 N95 masks, 12,975 pieces of personal protective equipment (PPE) and 10,000 medical gloves. The purpose of this donation is to aid Myanmar in its fight against COVID-19.
justification: Project involves donation of medical supplies for COVID-19 response, unrelated to energy or environmental impacts
evidence: Medical supplies including masks, PPE, and gloves provided for COVID-19 response

title: Government of China provides first batch of medical supplies worth RMB $1.5 million to Shan and Kachin regions of Myanmar in September 2021 (Linked to Project #96172)
description: On August 27, 2021, China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs donated medical supplies worth RMB $1.5 million to border regions of Myanmar, including Kachin and Shan states. The supplies includes protective materials, disinfectant, thermal scanners and oxygen generators. The purpose of this donation is to aid Myanmar in COVID-19 prevention efforts. A donation ceremony was also held in the Yunnan province of China. The donations will be delivered to Myitkyina, the capital of Kachin state, and then distributed to other areas. This is the first of two batches of donations from China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs to Myanmar's border regions. The other batch is recorded in Project #96172
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Government of China provides first batch of medical supplies worth RMB $1.5 million to Shan and Kachin regions of Myanmar in September 2021 (Linked to Project #96172)

# Description
On August 27, 2021, China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs donated medical supplies worth RMB $1.5 million to border regions of Myanmar, including Kachin and Shan states. The supplies includes protective materials, disinfectant, thermal scanners and oxygen generators. The purpose of this donation is to aid Myanmar in COVID-19 prevention efforts. A donation ceremony was also held in the Yunnan province of China. The donations will be delivered to Myitkyina, the capital of Kachin state, and then distributed to other areas. This is the first of two batches of donations from China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs to Myanmar's border regions. The other batch is recorded in Project #96172
justification: Project is focused on healthcare support and COVID-19 prevention, with no direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Medical supplies donation including protective materials, disinfectant, thermal scanners and oxygen generators for COVID-19 prevention

title: China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs provides second batch of medical supplies worth RMB $2.97 million to Shan region of Myanmar in September 2021 (Linked to Project #96166)
description: On September 5, 2021, China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs donated a second batch medical supplies worth RMB $2.97 million to the Shan region of Myanmar. The donation included surgical gloves, masks, hazmat suits, medicine, nucleic acid testing kits and oxygen generators, and the purpose of this donation was to aid Myanmar in COVID-19 prevention efforts. A donation ceremony was held on the same day in the city of Ruili in the Yunnan province of China. This is the second batch of medical supplies sent to Myanmar via China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs; the first batch was sent on August 27, 2021.

title: Government of China donates 3,000 tons of liquid oxygen to Myanmar in July 2021
description: On July 18, 2021, 3,000 tons of liquid oxygen arrived in the city of Mandalay in Myanmar from China. The purpose of this donation is to aid in COVID-19 relief efforts.

title: China's Yunnan Province donates liquid oxygen to Yangon region of Myanmar in August 2021
description: On August 5, 2021, China's Yunnan province donated liquid oxygen to Myanmar's Yangon region in order to aid in COVID-19 relief efforts. A donation ceremony was held for this donation at Waibagi Specialty General Hospital in Yangon. The liquid oxygen was to be distributed to local hospitals and treatment centers in Yangon.

A donation ceremony was held for this donation at Waibagi Specialty General Hospital in Yangon. The liquid oxygen was to be distributed to local hospitals and treatment centers in Yangon.
justification: Project is a humanitarian donation for healthcare purposes with no direct environmental or energy transition impact

title: People's Liberation Army of China donates COVID-19 prevention supplies to military of Myanmar in December 2021
description: On December 8, 2021, "COVID-19 epidemic prevention and control supplies" were donated to Myanmar's military by the People's Liberation Army of China. The purpose of this donation is to promote cooperation between the two nations, and offer support to Myanmar in anti-pandemic efforts.

title: Chinese Embassy in Myanmar donates COVID-19 supplies to China-Myanmar friendship schools in Sagaing region of Myanmar in August 2021
description: In August 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Myanmar made a donation of COVID-19 supplies to two China-Myanmar friendship schools in the Kalay township of the Sagaing region of Myanmar. The donation included masks, face shields, a batch of disinfectants, and hand sanitizers. The supplies were given around a similar time as another donation to the No. 1 Basic Education High School (Project 961870).
staff_comments: 1. Because the source does not give an exact date for the donations, AidData estimated the actual implementation start and actual completion dates as August 8th, the day before the article was published.
combined_text:

title: Chinese Embassy in Myanmar donates COVID-19 supplies to No. 1 Basic Education High School in Rakhine state of Myanmar
description: In August 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Myanmar donated COVID-19 supplies to over 1,300 teachers and students at the No. 1 Basic Education High School in the Kyaukphyu township of the Rakhine state of Myanmar. The donation included masks, face shields, disinfectants, and hand sanitizers. The supplies were handed over around the same time as donations to two China-Myanmar friendship schools in the Sagaing region of Myanmar (project #96186).
staff_comments: 1. Because the source does not give an exact date for the donations, AidData estimated the actual implementation start and actual completion dates as August 8th, the day before the article was published.

title: Chinese Embassy in Myanmar donates COVID-19 supplies to two high schools in Myanmar
description: On July 30th 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Myanmar made a donation of COVID-19 medical supplies to two high schools in Nay Pyi Taw, the capital of Myanmar. 50,000 surgical masks, 600 face shields, and a batch of hand sanitizers and disinfectants were donated to No. 7 Basic Education High School, while 60,000 surgical masks and a batch of hand sanitizers and disinfectants were donated to No. 14 Basic Education School.
staff_comments: AidData has estimated the transaction amount for this donation based on price catalogues from the World Health Organization (WHO). Please see the TUFF Methodology for additional details.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
Chinese Embassy in Myanmar donates COVID-19 supplies to two high schools in Myanmar

# Description
On July 30th 2021, the Chinese Embassy in Myanmar made a donation of COVID-19 medical supplies to two high schools in Nay Pyi Taw, the capital of Myanmar. 50,000 surgical masks, 600 face shields, and a batch of hand sanitizers and disinfectants were donated to No. 7 Basic Education High School, while 60,000 surgical masks and a batch of hand sanitizers and disinfectants were donated to No. 14 Basic Education School.
justification: Project is focused on healthcare support and social development, with no direct energy or environmental implications
evidence: Donation of COVID-19 medical supplies to schools, including masks, face shields, and sanitizers

title: China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Myanmar in 2021 (Linked to Project ID#98029)
description: In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI).   Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Myanmar signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under 4 buyer's credit loan (BCL) agreements and 3 government concessional loan (GCL) agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $75,694,000 ($62,591,000 in principal payments and $13,103,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period).   The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
staff_comments: 1. AidData assumes that the same basic terms and conditions that governed China Eximbank’s DSSI (debt suspension) agreement with other governments also applied to its DSSI agreement that it signed with the Government of Myanmar. Illustrative DSSI agreements can be accessed via https://www.dropbox.com/s/huwa695j3w9hwig/DSSI%20Agreement%20for%20Kyrgyz%20Republic.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/67n1oq44it27kvu/3.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20GCL%20Other%20Projects.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/n69i598f0fg7s80/6.%20Debt%20Suspension%20Agreement%20for%20PBC%20C2.pdf?dl=0. 2. The total estimated suspension amount is based on the size of the debt service deferral that the Government of Myanmar secured from the Chinese Government in 2021 (as recorded by the World Bank's Debtor Reporting System on December 6, 2022). See https://datatopics.worldbank.org/dssitables/deferrals/annual/MMR3. The debt suspension agreement with China Eximbank is documented in the Government of Myanmar’s Annual Government Debt Reports, which can be accessed via https://treasury.gov.mm/mm/Annual%20Report/5?language=eng and https://www.dropbox.com/s/l4y62ftatlyf5ik/2020-2021%20Fiscal%20Year%2C%20Annual%20Government%20Debt%20Report.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/gw4ansfleditxkn/2019-2020%20Fiscal%20Year%2C%20Annual%20Government%20Debt%20Report.pdf?dl=0 and https://www.dropbox.com/s/9jxog87dmzfsfgw/Government%20Debt%20Report%20for%20FY%2019-20%20V%20Final%20%2821-12-2021%29.pdf?dl=0.
combined_text:
# Sector
ACTION RELATING TO DEBT

# Title
China Eximbank suspends debt service payments from Government of Myanmar in 2021 (Linked to Project ID#98029)

# Description
In response to the COVID-19 pandemic and the G20 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors meeting that took place on April 15, 2020 and on November 13, 2020, the Chinese Government agreed to work with other G20 members to implement the Debt Service Suspension Initiative (DSSI).   Then, in 2021, China Eximbank and the Government of Myanmar signed a debt suspension agreement. Under the terms of the agreement, the lender agreed to suspend principal and interest payments due in 2021 under 4 buyer's credit loan (BCL) agreements and 3 government concessional loan (GCL) agreements. The total estimated suspension amount was $75,694,000 ($62,591,000 in principal payments and $13,103,000 in interest payments). However, at the time that the parties signed the debt suspension agreement, they both acknowledged that the total suspension amount would ultimately be determined at the end of the suspension period (since loan disbursements could be made during the suspension period and the lender agreed to suspend the payment of interest accrued on any disbursements during the suspension period).   The lender and borrower agreed that the suspension of debt service would be undertaken on a net present value (NPV)-neutral basis. Therefore, the borrower agreed to pay interest accrued on the amount outstanding under the total suspension amount (‘Suspension Interest’) by paying the Suspension Interest on the amount outstanding under each loan agreement’s suspension amount at the same rate of interest set forth in the original loan agreement.  Under the terms of the debt suspension agreement, the lender and the borrower also agreed that ‘[t]he suspension interest on the amount outstanding under the Suspension Amount concerning each Loan Agreement shall be calculated on the basis of the actual number of days elapsed and a year of 360 days, from and including the Repayment Date/Repayment Date of Principal and Interest falling within the Suspension Period to the date of payment in full of the corresponding Suspension Amount, and shall be paid in arrears on each Interest Payment Date under the corresponding Loan Agreement.’ The borrower also agreed that (1) ‘it shall continue to perform all its obligations […] under the Loan Agreements as supplemented and amended by [the debt suspension agreement]’; (2) ‘it shall use the created fiscal space to increase social, health, or economic spending in response to the COVID-19 crisis […]’ and ‘work closely with the International Financial Institutions who are expected to put in place a monitoring system’;  (3) ‘it shall disclose to the Lender all Public Sector Financial Commitments (as defined in the Government Finance Statistics Manual 2014 (GFSM2014)), respecting commercially sensitive information’; and (4) ‘it shall contract no new non-concessional debt during the Suspension Period, other than agreements under the DSSI’.
justification: Project involves debt service suspension and financial arrangements without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Debt suspension agreement, financial terms and conditions, COVID-19 response measures
